meanings.definition: To declare someone not guilty of a criminal charge.
meanings.sent1: The jury was acquitting the defendant after hearing all the evidence.
meanings.sent2: The judge will be acquitting the accused based on lack of proof.
meanings.sent3: The courtroom erupted in cheers as the verdict of acquitting was announced.
meanings.sent4: The innocence shining in his eyes was like the act of acquitting his soul.
meanings.sent5: The weight of the gavel striking down echoed the finality of acquitting the defendant.

meanings.definition: To perform one's duty or responsibility satisfactorily.
meanings.sent1: She was acquitting herself well in her new role at the company.
meanings.sent2: The firefighter was acquitting his duty by rescuing the trapped cat.
meanings.sent3: Even under pressure, he was acquitting his tasks with a calm demeanor.
meanings.sent4: Her dedication to excellence was acquitting her as a reliable team member.
meanings.sent5: The teacher was acquitting her responsibilities with passion and care for her students.

meanings.definition: To free someone from a duty or obligation.
meanings.sent1: The manager was acquitting the employee from the extra workload.
meanings.sent2: The kind gesture of acquitting her from the assignment was appreciated.
meanings.sent3: He felt relieved after acquitting his friend from the promise to help move.
meanings.sent4: The waiver was like acquitting him from the burden of attending the meeting.
meanings.sent5: The act of acquitting her from the task allowed her to focus on other priorities.
